questions.question: 1. Which muscle is NOT considered part of the lateral abdominal wall?
2. What structure divides the two rectus abdominis muscles along the midline?
3. Below the arcuate line, the posterior wall of the rectus sheath is formed primarily by which structure?
options: Aponeuroses of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.question: 4. The lateral margin of the rectus abdominis is known as the:
5. Which muscle represents the deepest layer of the anterior abdominal wall?
6. The conjoint tendon (falx inguinalis) is formed by the fusion of the aponeuroses of which muscles?
7. Which area of the anterior abdominal wall is a recognized weak point where hernias commonly occur?
8. What are the primary functions of the anterior abdominal wall muscles?
9. Which muscles form the principal components of the posterior abdominal wall?
options: Psoas major, Iliacus, and Quadratus lumborum

questions.question: 10. What structure covers the anterior surface of the posterior abdominal wall?
options: Posterior layer of the rectus sheath

questions.question: 11. Which thick aponeurotic structure envelops the deep muscles of the back and contributes to the posterior abdominal wall?
12. The midline raphe formed by the fusion of the aponeuroses from both sides of the anterior abdominal wall is called the:
13. What is the significance of the arcuate line in relation to the rectus sheath?
options: It marks the upper limit of the rectus sheath.
Below it, the posterior rectus sheath is absent and only the transversalis fascia covers the rectus muscle.
It forms the lateral border of the rectus abdominis.
It is the midline fusion of the aponeuroses.

questions.question: 14. Which structure forms the anterior wall of the inguinal canal?
15. Which of the following is NOT a component of the posterior abdominal wall?
